Yes. This is only an issue in bedrock edition and should be fixed. The bug report was closed but this decision should be reverted.

https://bugs.mojang.com/browse/MCPE-38138

I'm gonna have to say no to this. Barrier blocks are for map makers to prevent people from going out of the map with ender pearls or ladders or whatever. Making rain and snow not go though barrier blocks would reduce creativity (no more rain or snow on maps that need barrier blocks), something that goes directly against the themes of the game. If you don't want rain or snow, just turn it off as I'm pretty sure you can in bedrock anyway.

If they removed the bone and nether wart blocks, it would be way harder to store all of your bones and nether warts, and ruin a lot of builds that use them. as for the terracotta, if you removed that, your entire mesa biome would be a huge crater.

 

Very, very bad idea.
He is correct. That would ruin the game.
I would like to clear up the inventory, but every block I can think of has its purpose.

As TheFriendlyPine pointed out: Storage. You can convert bone blocks back into bone meal, but not bone meal back into bones. You can turn nether warts into nether wart blocks, but not nether wart blocks back into nether warts. All these "unnecessary blocks" are good for decoration. They are intended for decoration. The bone blocks are also used for random structures throughout the Minecraft world. This is a bad idea in my opinion indeed.
Maybe just more inventory tabs for better organization and fewer blocks per tab?
If you wanna clear the inventory, drop things into lava or onto cacti. lol
If you don't like them, don't use them.  If it "ruins" the simplicity of the game, good!  Minecraft isn't supposed to be simple.  The more content, the better!
If you don’t like them you can make a mod to remove them!

I have certain doubts that these would work. Redstone delays are already in the game with repeaters so something like that is unlikely. After the new crafting overhaul I doubt they would add more crafting/tool blocks but the idea of frozen versions of blocks could be very cool both for mechanical uses and for looks :)
Why "frozen redstone"? Wouldn't that just block its power?
This sounds like an icebox, except currently it wouldn't be all that useful as frozen things do not melt in inventories and food does not rot at all
It actually exists in ReIndev.
I am Soooooo confused right now.
I am confused too.

Say you are build a two story house and you half to be made from stone and top wood.  you put he trowel in hand and place 64 stone in slot 2, 3 and 4.  Place 64 wood in slot 5, 6 and 7.  When the trowel is used on the ground, it will removed 1 stone and wood from each slot 2 through 7 and stack the on the ground. 3 stone on the bottom and 3 wood on top.  The idea is to build 6 time faster.

If I have interpreted this correctly, the idea is to have a tool which places blocks vertically in the order of the blocks in your hot bar. For example: You have cobblestone, oak wood and leaves in your hot bar then when used the tool will place the 3 blocks on top of each other. A quick way of building upwards faster :)

I like this idea but I doubt something like this will be added. It doesn't seem (in my eyes) to be something they would add because it takes away from the Minecraft experience. Building towers in 10 seconds takes away from the theme of building in survival as well as think about how they have just added scaffolding, a really smart block to help people build vertically in a natural building way.

Also think about multiplayer, if an item like this was spammed it could cause major lag and could be a possible greifing tool.

I like this idea :D

However it wouldn't make sense for use in walls as bricks are meant to be built from side to side for structural integrity, I understand Minecraft isn't completely based off realism but keeping bricks simple as a block has benefits such as ease of use and consistency.

There is definitely uses for this though, i.e using as a floor, changing the direction of bricks would be very useful in that case.

I think this relates to a bigger issue in Minecraft which is how differently each block is used in builds and the mechanics behind each block. I think if the Mojang team focused on creating a block similar to the carpenters block from the carpenters mod. Something like a block you can change to properties of (with a tool) which can have the skin of any block you want. This would help a lot of builders out in the game without them having to edit every block to have different properties.

Carpenters block mod for reference: https://www.minecraftforum.net/forums/mapping-and-modding-java-edition/minecraft-mods/1288875-carpenters-blocks

Water can't be placed in the Nether, meaning that the player would have to grow quartz outside of the Nether which would effectively remove a reason for going to the Nether.

I think quartz should simply be more common. You would still find the same veins as usual, but you can occasionally find caves filled with crystalline pillars of Raw Nether Quartz which would drop regular Nether Quartz unless Silk Touch is used.

Translation “ This furnace would be used to melt minerals to obtain metal alloys. This gold would be created with a blast furnace, a cauldron, a hopper, and 6 iron ingots. One of the combinations could be coal and iron to obtain liquid steel, which would be collected with a bucket by right-clicking on the furnace. Then, with the full bucket, right-click on a cauldron of water to get cooled steel. This cooled steel would be placed on an anvil to obtain a steel ingot, which would yield armor with more durability and defense, tools with more durability and damage, a steel bow with greater range and stability, and arrows with more damage. Redstone could also be mixed with other minerals to create redstone with enhanced attributes.”

Now some ideas that people suggest a lot but wouldn't work and why (and how some of them could have an use):

Emerald: Too easy and cheap to get in early game to be better than iron, too expensive and unnecesary if it's worse than iron. There's no reason for it to be in the game UNLESS it has some special characteristic like how gold has the highest enchantability

Quartz: Same than emerald but with less potential in special characteristics and too similar to iron

Wood/Stone: The dumbest ideas; too cheap, unnecesary, don't make sense... These would either be terrible or break the game's progression

Lapis: Unless it has something special with enchanting or xp (like not requiring xp to enchant or giving more xp when using the tools) it just doesn't serve any purpose and even then it seems unnecesary or even unbalanced for some enchantments. Again too easy to get in high quantities so it shouldn't be too good but then it seems better to just use iron or anything else

Amethyst: Probably the dumbest idea but with some potential. If this is ever added it should probably have bad stats but with some unique and magical use like reducing potion time or enchantments effect. If not this just seems unnecesary and useless

Titanium: Just doesn't make sense in the Minecraft age and doesn't serve much purpose (or at least there's better options that could do the same and more)

Silver: It's stronger than gold but weaker than copper... Then what could it do? Since it's the most conductive metal it could maybe have some utility related to that or something magical, but then a tool and armor set isn't the best idea

Tin: Same than silver. There's better uses for it

ada y con eso podrás hacerte una armadura de obsidiana reforzada!

Ventajas:resistencia alta! Durabilidad muy fuerte! Incluso más que la del diamante! Es un poco resistente al fuego junto tu también! Incluso en la lava! Pero solo un poco! Puedes morir en la lava aun y la armadura quemarse en la lava! Aun que también eres resistente a las explosiones! En el sentido que no te mandaran a volar tan fácilmente! Incluso eres bastante resistente al creeper!

Desventajas:eres más lento que con otras armaduras! Dado que su peso sería... Algo alto dado su durabilidad! A la vez deberías tener cuidado con caer desde un lugar alto con esa armadura dado que el peso de la armadura hará que te hagas más daño que otras armaduras por lo pesado (y resistente) qué es! Así que es mejor que no saltes por ahí desde lugares altos!
so tuff
Too op, but a weapon that drains durability rather than doing damage could be a good idea, specialy against shields (It could be anoying tho)

This could also make the Recovery Compass a bit more useful as well. Typically if you die you are close enough to remember where you died, so you don't need the compass. But if you died really far away, you might not remember where you died so the compass might be useful, but by the time you get there your items may have despawned. Having the Sculk Tombstone would allow your items to be saved while you use the Recovery Compass to locate it
The items could be buried in the sculk blocks, kind of like suspicious sand/gravel
This could be a potion effect, like the potion of weaving. You drink it before you death and when you die it spreads sculk
The crafter literally does this

To improve everyday gameplay:

  • Potions stack up to 16.

  • Ender chests with the same name should share the same inventory and be bundle-compatible.

  • Quivers (crafted with leather and string) store multiple arrow stacks.

  • TNT minecarts could stack up to 16.

  • Totems of Undying could be enchantable — Power V for stronger effects, Efficiency V for longer duration, and Infinity for reactivation every five minutes.

  • The Elytra Chestplate would negate knockback resistance to wind charges and explosions.

Other small but immersive features could include:

  • Tool trims and banner customization (as Nekoma suggested).

  • Feather punching doing no damage but light knockback.

  • Feather Falling preventing crop trampling.

  • Lantern-on-a-stick utility item.

  • Improved tipped arrow and watermelon mechanics.

  • Copper grates can be used as conveyor belts that use water flow inside.

Lastly, Mojang could partner with major clients and custom cape software so verified custom capes are visible to everyone, showing the client’s logo next to the player’s name in the tab list.

These ideas would fix many gameplay limits, make late-game survival more interesting, and tie the community’s creativity more closely to Minecraft’s core game.
not very vanilla, i dont think much of this would be added
